item.title: U.K. Doubles Down on a Tactic Disproportionately Targeting Black People
item.description: The United States helped inspire Britain’s tough-on-crime politics. Even as crime fell and warnings mounted, politicians never looked back.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joint enterprise is a legal principle that gives prosecutors the power to charge multiple people with a single crime.

item.title: In an Era of Confrontation, Biden and Xi Seek to Set Terms
item.description: Their first in-person presidential meeting, coming after both warned of deepening military, economic and diplomatic rivalry, will show how they address a range of U.S.-China tensions.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden in Egypt on Friday.

item.title: Ukraine Signals It Will Stay on the Offensive, Despite Talk of a Lull
item.description: Many analysts and diplomats have suggested there could be a pause in major combat, and even peace talks, over the winter, but after pushing the Russians out of Kherson, Ukraine has no desire to stop.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the village of Snihurivka, in southern Ukraine, on Thursday, the day after Russia formally announced it had retreated from villages along the Kherson front.

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Work to Secure Kherson City
item.description: The Ukrainian military said it was clearing left-behind mines and explosives, while still battling Russian forces on its outskirts.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Friday in a former Russian base filled with mortar rounds, ammunition and discarded uniforms in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine.

item.title: Can the Rhine River Be Saved From Climate Change?
item.description: Germany has embarked on an ambitious and expensive effort to preserve the river’s historical role as a vital transportation link. But will it work?
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Laetitia Vancon
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Entering Kherson Are Greeted With Joy
item.description: After months of Russian occupation, residents said the moment recalled being liberated from the Nazis in World War II. But there was also fear about further Russian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anna Lukinova and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: via Reuters
item.media:description: From social media on Friday: Tearing down a Russia poster in Bilozerka, Kherson region; a crowd cheering Ukrainian soldiers in Kherson Freedom Square; a Ukrainian flag on top of a statue at the Freedom Square.

item.title: Nepal Fights Deforestation, and Wins
item.description: An effort decades in the making is showing results in Nepal, a rare success story in a world of cascading climate disasters and despair.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Karan Deep Singh/The New York Times
item.media:description: The community forests in Khairahani, Nepal, stretching over several tree-capped hills in March.

item.title: After 4 Sons Vanish, Their Mother Devotes Her Life to Mexico’s Missing
item.description: Over 100,000 people are missing in Mexico, but even amid this national agony, one mother’s story stands out both for the scope of her suffering and for her work trying to end the nation’s nightmare.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: After María Herrera Magdaleno’s four sons disappeared, she began advocating for all parents in Mexico with missing children.

item.title: Large Earthquake Strikes Near Tonga, Setting Off Tsunami Warnings
item.description: Officials advised people to get to the third floor of buildings if they were unable to flee to higher ground. Videos showed drivers trying to escape the danger.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: POIS Christopher Szumlanski/Australian Defense Force, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Damage on Atata Island, Tonga, in February after a volcanic eruption triggered a tsunami.

item.title: On Alibaba’s Singles Day, Chinese Brands Fill Shopping Baskets
item.description: As geopolitical and economic pressures mount, homegrown businesses are increasingly the preferred choice over Western competitors in a more insular China.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Preparing Singles Day deliveries in Lianyungang, China. Like Black Friday, Singles Day has morphed into a sales event that lasts for weeks.

item.title: China Eases Some Pandemic Policies, While Sticking to ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: Investors cheered the changes, although officials emphasized that measures “must not be relaxed.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Hector Retamal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Passengers waiting to be transported to quarantine hotels after arriving at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai in January.

item.title: Belgium Police Killing May Have Been Terrorism, Officials Say
item.description: The suspect was on the government’s watch list of potential extremists. Attacks have been rare in Europe in the past few years.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Geert Vanden Wijngaert/Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers in a cordoned-off area in Brussels on Friday near the spot where two of their colleagues were stabbed the night before.

item.title: A Vatican Auditor Says He Dug Up Too Much Dirt, and Was Buried
item.description: Libero Milone is suing the Vatican for wrongful dismissal after he said he found cardinals siphoning off funds. The Vatican has hit him with a criminal investigation of its own.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: L'Osservatore Romano/via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pope Francis meeting with Libero Milone, now a former Vatican auditor general, in a 2016 photo released by a Vatican newspaper.

item.title: Norwegian Princess Engaged to Shaman Gives Up Royal Duties
item.description: Princess Martha Louise’s belief in the supernatural has long been the subject of media fascination in Norway, but a focus on her healer fiancé proved too much.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Lise Aserud/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Princess Martha Louise of Norway and her fiancé, Durek Verrett, in Oslo, in June.

item.title: Viewing Party
item.description: There’s so much to watch over the next few weeks that you might need to make a schedule.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch
item.category: Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s Government Sharpens Criticism of China
item.description: Mr. Trudeau and his cabinet ministers are calling on democracies to increasingly turn their backs on China and other autocratic nations.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Damir Sagolj/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau with President Xi Jinping of China in 2016 when their relations were very different.

item.title: Internal Documents Show How Close the F.B.I. Came to Deploying Spyware
item.description: Christopher Wray, the F.B.I.’s director, told Congress last December that the bureau purchased the phone hacking tool Pegasus for research purposes.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, acknowledged that the bureau considered deploying the hacking tool.

item.title: Winter Will Be a Major Factor in the Ukraine War, Officials Say
item.description: Both sides are expected to pause operations. But heavy snows and freezing temperatures could make it difficult for the poorly equipped Russian army to regroup.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian armored vehicle returning from the frontline in the city of Kupiansk-Vuzlovyi in the Kharkiv region. Ukraine will need a long-term buildup of tanks and other weapons to make advances.

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Enter Kherson, a Strategic Prize, in a Blow to Putin
item.description: Jubilant crowds poured into the streets, greeting Ukrainian soldiers and waving flags. But officials said the city was not out of danger, warning of potential Russian reprisals.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers walking through a former Russian base filled with mortar rounds, ammunition, and discarded Russian uniforms in Blahodatne, in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Court to Reconsider Trump-Era Decision That Favored Alaska Road Project
item.description: Conservation groups, joined by former President Carter, had sued to reopen the case after a March ruling upheld an Interior Department deal for a road through a national wildlife refuge.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.category: Izembek National Wildlife Refuge and Wilderness
item.media:credit: Acacia Johnson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A brown bear near the boundary of Izembek National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska.

item.title: At COP27, Biden Casts America as Climate Leader, While Activists Push Him to Do More
item.description: At climate talks in Egypt, President Biden apologized for his predecessor’s decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden addressing the United Nations climate conference on Friday, one of the few world leaders of a major polluting country to attend. “The United States is acting,” he said. “Everyone has to act.”

item.title: UK Bird Flu Fears Force Even the Tower of London’s Ravens Inside
item.description: A highly contagious strain of the avian flu has prompted the British government to order precautions.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The ravens at the Tower of London were isolated amid an outbreak of avian flu in Britain.

item.title: For Biden and Xi, a Long Relationship With Rising Mutual Suspicion
item.description: The men, who first met as vice presidents, plan to hold face-to-face talks for the first time as national leaders, and at a time when animus defines U.S.-China relations.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Edward Wong
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:credit: Peter Parks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In 2011, Xi Jinping and Joseph R. Biden Jr., both vice presidents at the time, near Chengdu, China.

item.title: As Ukraine Makes Gains, Mykolaiv Bears Fierce Russian Attacks
item.description: The Ukrainian city keeps getting bombed by the Russians just as nearby Kherson appears to be falling back into the hands of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: An apartment block in the Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv that was damaged overnight by Russian bombardment, killing at least seven people.

item.title: Explosion on a Kherson Bridge Severs the City’s Last Major Crossing
item.description: Videos and photographs posted to social media showed the Antonivsky Bridge to be heavily damaged.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:credit: Maxar Technologies/AP
item.media:description: This satellite image shows the northern span of the damaged Antonivsky Bridge, in Kherson, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Seeks Closer Ties With India as Tension With China and Russia Builds
item.description: Treasury Secretary Yellen wants India to be part of the Biden administration’s “friend-shoring” agenda, but trade tensions linger.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Manish Swarup/Associated Press
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen was welcomed by Anant Maheshwari of Microsoft at the Microsoft India Development Center in Noida, on the outskirts of New Delhi, on Friday.

item.title: Unconventional Results
item.description: In states where abortion rights or democracy was on the ballot, Democrats upended the typical midterm result.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Pennsylvania before the election.

item.title: KFC Apologizes for Kristallnacht Promotion
item.description: An automated push notification sent in error by KFC Germany conflated the notorious 1938 pogrom and “tender cheese with crispy chicken.”
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Melissa Eddy
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Axel Heimken/picture alliance via Getty Images
item.media:description: A KFC restaurant in Hamburg, Germany, in 2018.

item.title: Zelensky says dozens of towns and villages in the Kherson region have been retaken.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers celebrating the withdrawal by Russian troops in Snihurivka, on the Kherson front in southern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: When It Comes to Bearing Bad Tidings, Putin Is Nowhere to Be Found
item.description: Big decisions about Ukraine are President Vladimir V. Putin’s to make, but the Kremlin and state media are distancing him from the setback in Kherson and downplaying its seriousness.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released by Russia’s Defense Ministry showing President Vladimir V. Putin, second right, Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, left, and Anatoly Kontsevoy, deputy commander of the airborne troops, second left, at a military training center in the Ryazan region last month.

item.title: Can There Be a Rights Reckoning for Nations That Don’t Want to Do It?
item.description: In nations reckoning with atrocities, reconciliation panels and similar bodies often obscure or delay the truth. But that doesn’t mean that international justice has no effect.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women who accuse the Sri Lankan security forces of disappearing their sons have been the driving force of protests in the country, including this one in the town of Mullaitivu in 2018.

item.title: The Australian Teacher Fighting to Be the World’s Strongest Woman
item.description: Elly Smith competes in a sport called strongman, where participants attempt to lift, hold, pull or carry everything from dumbbells to airplanes.
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra
item.media:credit: Hayley Bell
item.media:description: From Friday to Sunday, Elly Smith will vie for the title of World’s Strongest Woman at a competition in Daytona Beach, Fla.

item.title: Top U.S. General Urges Diplomacy in Ukraine While Biden Advisers Resist
item.description: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has made the case that the Ukrainians should try to cement their gains at the bargaining table.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden flanked by Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III, left, and Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at the White House last month.

item.title: Data Shows Carbon Dioxide Emissions Likely to Reach Record High in 2022
item.description: Global emissions from fossil fuels are likely to reach record highs this year, new data shows, putting nations further off track from stopping global warming.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Ritesh Shukla/Getty Images
item.media:description: A coal mine in Uttar Pradesh, India, which accounts for 8 percent of the world’s carbon dioxide emissions. China is responsible for 32 percent, the United States 14 percent and the European Union 8 percent.

item.title: Ukraine Moves Forward in South, With Little Resistance From Russia
item.description: A day after Russia said it was withdrawing from Kherson City in the south, Ukraine’s forces moved into villages without a fight, indicating the Russians were, indeed, retreating.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian woman wept on Thursday after Ukrainian soldiers entered the village of Snihurivka, which had been occupied by Russian soldiers.

item.title: Qatar Will Allow Israelis to Fly Directly to Doha for World Cup
item.description: The move fell short of creating formal diplomatic ties between the countries, but it was the latest sign of warming relations between Israel and some Arab governments.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Jewel Samad/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The FIFA World Cup will begin in Qatar on Nov. 20.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Xi and Biden to Meet
item.description: Plus cryptocurrency chaos and Ukraine’s wary advance toward Kherson.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Food prices have been high for months.

item.title: How Europe Is Reacting to the US Midterm Elections
item.description: With the MAGA star dimmed, analysts expect continued support in Washington for Ukraine and NATO, and perhaps greater pressure on China.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Capitol in Washington after Election Day. The shape of the next Congress is still unsettled, but reactions from abroad were already coming in.

item.title: ‘How Did This Man Think He Had the Right to Adopt This Baby?’
item.description: Army Rangers killed her parents. A Marine is raising her in America. But her Afghan family says she was taken under false pretenses.
item.dc:creator: Rozina Ali
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Brazil Counted All Its Votes in Hours. It Still Faces Fraud Claims.
item.description: A report from the military found no voter fraud — but left room for Bolsonaro’s supporters to argue maybe he’d actually won.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro demonstrated last week in São Paulo after his electoral defeat, calling for military intervention.

item.title: Biden and Xi to Meet as Tensions Grow Over Taiwan
item.description: Setting a meeting gives the two leaders an opportunity for face-to-face time, but President Biden said he would deliver no “fundamental concessions” over Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China are also expected to discuss trade, human rights and North Korea.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Each Have Over 100,000 Casualties, Top US General Says
item.description: Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called the coming winter months an opportune time for the two sides to hold peace talks, though that prospect appears dim.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank in a field in Petrivka, an area of the Kherson region that Ukraine recaptured in early October.

item.title: 84 Years Later, a Rare Look at the Nazi Attacks of Kristallnacht
item.description: The photographs of the assaults on Jews during the 1938 pogrom, which is widely commemorated as the start of the Holocaust, had been kept by a former American serviceman.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Yad Vashem, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released by Yad Vashem, the World Holocaust Remembrance Center, of German Nazis and civilians watching the ransacking of Jewish property during the attacks, known as Kristallnacht, taken most likely in the town of Fürth, Germany, on Nov. 10, 1938.

item.title: In France, an Outburst Is a Setback for the Far Right
item.description: For the first time, the National Rally is the main opposition party in Parliament. But can it use its new perch to convince voters it has changed?
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Thibault Camus/Associated Press
item.media:description: Carlos Martens Bilongo, center right, and Mathilde Panot, both members of Parliament, at a rally outside the National Assembly in Paris on Friday. Their colleague was punished for shouting “Back to Africa!” while Mr. Bilongo was speaking.

item.title: Biden’s COP27 Climate Message Might Not Be the One the World Wants
item.description: The president is expected to hail the new U.S. climate law on Friday at the COP27 summit in Egypt. Other countries want to talk money.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at the White House on Wednesday. He is scheduled to appear at the United Nations climate talks, known as COP27, in Egypt on Friday.

item.title: Abortion on the Ballot
item.description: Democrats won crucial races in states where abortion rights were at stake.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion rights advocate in Taylor, Mich. last week.

item.title: Egypt Starts ‘Medical Intervention’ on Prominent Political Prisoner, Family Says
item.description: The hunger-striking dissident Alaa Abd El Fattah escalated his protest this week when he stopped drinking water as a U.N. climate conference opened in Egypt. His family fears that he is being force fed.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Alaa Abd El Fattah in 2015 in Cairo’s Tora prison.

item.title: Weed Is Legal in Thailand. How Long Will the High Times Last?
item.description: Cannabis shops have multiplied since the drug was decriminalized, with caveats, in June. But some lawmakers are pushing for tighter regulation.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Weighing dried cannabis flowers for a customer at Chopaka.

item.title: In an Age of Constant Disaster, What Does It Mean to Rebuild?
item.description: Each catastrophe is a test of what kind of society we’ve built. And each recovery offers a chance, however fleeting, to build another.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Thompson
item.media:credit: Jamie Chung for The New York Times. Concept by Pablo Delcan. Prop stylist: JJ Chan.

item.title: Putin Will Not Attend the G20 Summit
item.description: The Russian delegation will be headed by Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov, the RIA Novosti state news agency reported.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin taking part in a video conference during the G20 Leaders’ Summit 2020, at the Novo-Ogaryovo state residence outside Moscow.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Takeaways from the U.S. midterms.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden discussing the election results at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Peace Talks Remain Distant Even as Moscow Signals a Retreat
item.description: President Biden and European leaders say they cannot push Ukraine and Russia into negotiations, though some U.S. lawmakers are questioning aid for an open-ended war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers ride atop an armored vehicle. President Biden and European leaders are hard-pressed to describe a plausible endgame to the conflict that would be acceptable to both sides.

item.title: Brittney Griner Transferred to Russian Penal Colony
item.description: The U.S. basketball star, detained for more than eight months so far, is being transferred to an undisclosed prison in Russia, her lawyers said. The United States denounced the move.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, shown during a court appearance in August, has been detained for more than eight months.

item.title: Russia Orders Retreat From Kherson, a Serious Reversal in the Ukraine War
item.description: Russia’s position had grown perilous in Kherson, a strategic city and one of the biggest prizes seized in its Ukraine invasion, but Russian hawks reacted angrily to the withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer, Dan Bilefsky, Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Stanislav Kozliuk/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Kherson area on Wednesday. The announced retreat from the city is one of the most significant setbacks for Russia in the war so far.

item.title: At COP27, Plans to Overhaul the IMF and World Bank Gain Traction
item.description: As global warming delivers cascading weather disasters, leaders at U.N. climate talks say it’s time to radically overhaul the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nigel R. Browne/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mia Mottley of Barbados during preparations in the country’s capital, Bridgetown, for Tropical Storm Dorian in 2019.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: No ‘Red Wave’ in U.S. Midterms
item.description: Plus Russia says it is retreating from Kherson City and markets try to parse China’s “zero Covid.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters lined up in Georgia on Election Day, where the race between incumbent Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock and his Republican challenger, Herschel Walker, was so close it will go to a runoff election in December.

item.title: In Wake of U.S. Election, Ukrainian Lawmakers Will Reach Out to Washington
item.description: Officials are optimistic that Washington will continue to support the war effort. But a delegation is planning a trip to meet lawmakers of both parties.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States is by far the largest provider of weapons to Ukraine, including Javelin antitank missiles.

item.title: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Debut Overshadowed By Williamson Resignation
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s pragmatic diplomacy did not grab attention the way the resignation of a cabinet minister did.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andy Bailey/UK Parliament, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by the British Parliament showing Prime Minister Rishi Sunak during prime minister's questions in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin Stays Silent on the Kherson Withdrawal Order
item.description: Some analysts saw the order as a reminder of President Vladimir Putin’s willingness to make tactical concessions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Sergej Bobylev
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russian did not address the announced withdrawal, letting others do the talking.
